column1: Kineshma (Russian: Кинешма) is the second largest town in Ivanovo Oblast
column3: which sprawls for 15 kilometers (9.3 mi) along the Volga River. Population: 88

column1: Kineshma was first noticed as a posad in 1429.  In 1504
column2: Ivan III gave it to Prince Feodor Belsky
column3: who escaped to Moscow from Lithuania and married Ivan's niece. Later on
column4: Ivan the Terrible gave Kineshma to Ivan Petrovich Shuisky
column5: but after the latter's death it was returned to the Tsar in 1587. In the 16th and 17th centuries
column6: Kineshma was a major fishing center
column7: which supplied sturgeon for the Tsar's table. In 1608
column8: it was twice ravaged by the Poles. Throughout its history
column9: Kineshma belonged to different Russian regions
column11: Yaroslavl Province of Saint Petersburg Governorate

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Kineshma serves as the administrative center of Kineshemsky District
column3: even though it is not a part of it. As an administrative division
column4: it is incorporated separately as the Town of Kineshma—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column5: the Town of Kineshma is incorporated as Kineshma Urban Okrug.

column2: the town's main industry has been textile manufacturing. Like all the textile centers in Russia
column3: the town's prosperity declined after the perestroika.

column1: Kineshma's principal landmark is the Trinity Cathedral
column2: built in 1838–1845 to a typical Neoclassical design. There are also several 18th-century churches in the town. The neighborhoods of Kineshma contain estates and museums of Alexander Ostrovsky
Kineshma was granted status of a town of historical significance.
